content.subtitle: Hello, Dart developers! The latest stable version, Dart 3.9, is officially here!

paragraphs.name: 519d
paragraphs.text: Announcing Dart 3.9

paragraphs.name: cf1f
paragraphs.text: Hello, Dart developers! The latest stable version, Dart 3.9, is officially here!

paragraphs.name: 341a
paragraphs.text: This release is all about making your work easier and your apps more efficient. With key updates to null safety, performance boosts to the Dart CLI, and the exciting addition of the Dart and Flutter MCP Server to empower your AI assistants, there’s a lot to love. Read on to discover everything that’s new in Dart 3.9.
Announcing Dart 3.9

paragraphs.name: 4b6b
paragraphs.text: Language updates

paragraphs.name: 8cea
paragraphs.text: Null safety

paragraphs.name: eb75
paragraphs.text: Dart 3.9 assumes null safety when computing type promotion, reachability, and definite assignment. To take advantage of these improvements, set your package’s SDK constraint lower bound to 3.9 or greater (sdk: ^3.9.0). As a result of this change, more dead_code warnings may be produced.
Soundness updates

paragraphs.name: 79ee
paragraphs.text: We fixed a soundness issue that allowed direct invocation of a value returned from a getter without any runtime checks when the getter’s return type was a generic type argument instantiated as dynamic or Function. This soundness issue arose with the dev-compiler DDC, and no other tools are affected.
Before the fix the following getter could trigger an issue with a direct invocation. For example:

paragraphs.name: fc51
76cc
paragraphs.text: Tools updates

paragraphs.name: e248
paragraphs.text: Dart and Flutter MCP Server

paragraphs.name: 4bef
paragraphs.text: The Dart and Flutter MCP Server acts as a bridge, giving AI coding assistants such as Gemini CLI, Cursor, and GitHub Copilot, access to more of your Dart project’s context. Instead of just suggesting code, your AI assistant can now understand your project deeply and take action on your behalf.

paragraphs.name: fca1
paragraphs.text: With the Dart and Flutter MCP Server, you can ask an AI assistant to:
Fix runtime errors (see example).

paragraphs.name: 227a
paragraphs.text: Manage dependencies (see example).

paragraphs.name: bd39
paragraphs.text: Write and correct code.

paragraphs.name: cb9a
paragraphs.text: And more.

paragraphs.name: 51e9
paragraphs.text: The Dart and Flutter MCP Server is now available on the stable channel of the Dart SDK.
Fixing a layout issue, enabled by the Dart and Flutter MCP Server (parts of this recording have been sped up)

paragraphs.name: e3dc
paragraphs.text: Faster Dart CLI

paragraphs.name: a506
paragraphs.text: Previously, when you ran some Dart CLI commands like dart analyze and dart fix, your computer had to compile the code for the analysis server just before running it. Now, these tools use an Ahead-Of-Time (AOT) compiled snapshot of the analysis server, which means the server has been pre-compiled into fast, native machine code.

paragraphs.name: 80f6
paragraphs.text: Results vary depending on the source code, but we ran some common commands on a sample package and got some interesting results. Some short commands like dart format now complete in a fraction of the time and longer running ones like dart analyze got nearly 50% faster.

paragraphs.name: 7ce9
paragraphs.text: Example performance results after the Dart CLI update

paragraphs.name: 72ed
paragraphs.text: pub client updates

paragraphs.name: 69d9
paragraphs.text: Git dependencies can now be version-solved based on git tags.

paragraphs.name: 95c5
paragraphs.text: When you use a tag_pattern in the descriptor and there is a version constraint, all commits matching the pattern are considered during resolution. In the following example, only version 2.0.1 of my_dependency and higher is considered:

paragraphs.name: eb61
paragraphs.text:
dependencies:
  my_dependency:
    git:
      url: https://github.com/example/my_dependency
      tag_pattern: v{{version}}
    version: ^2.0.1

paragraphs.name: e4b9
paragraphs.text: Starting from language version 3.9, the flutter constraint upper bound is now respected in your root package (the dart constraint was already respected). Setting a narrow dart or flutter constraint can be useful to ensure a team of developers all use the same SDK version when jointly developing an app (see issue #95472 for details).

paragraphs.name: 9b54
paragraphs.text: For example, in a root pubspec like this pub get will fail if invoked with a version of the Flutter SDK that is not 3.33.0:

paragraphs.name: 96b4
paragraphs.text:
name: my_app
environment:
  sdk: ^3.9.0
  flutter: 3.33.0

paragraphs.name: 0b77
paragraphs.text: Dart native compiler

paragraphs.name: 44ac
paragraphs.text: We added cross-compilation support for target architectures of arm (ARM32) and riscv64 (RV64GC) when the target OS is Linux.
Deprecations & breaking changes

paragraphs.name: 85d8
paragraphs.text: 32-bit x86 architecture

paragraphs.name: aa62
paragraphs.text: Dart has deprecated the 32-bit x86 architecture. For most developers this will have no impact, as it mainly affects older x86-based Android emulators and a small number of physical devices. 32-bit ARM and 64-bit x86_64 emulators and devices are still supported. The full technical breakdown is available in the Dart GitHub deprecation issue.

paragraphs.name: 4c65
paragraphs.text: dart build

paragraphs.name: bc2f
paragraphs.text: dart build is in preview on the beta channel.

paragraphs.name: 23fa
paragraphs.text: dart build -f exe <target> is now dart build cli — target=<target>. See dart build cli — help for more info.

paragraphs.name: 4cc1
paragraphs.text: Wrap up

paragraphs.name: 1b62
paragraphs.text: That’s a wrap on Dart 3.9! We hope you’re as excited about these updates as we are. We always appreciate your feedback, so feel free to share your thoughts. Until next time, happy coding!

virtuals.subtitle: Hello, Dart developers! The latest stable version, Dart 3.9, is officially here!
